questions.text: A 45-year-old female smoker presents with chronic hoarseness and low-pitched voice. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals bilateral fusiform swelling of the membranous vocal cords. Biopsy shows edematous changes without malignancy. The swelling is most likely due to edema in which of the following anatomical spaces?
questions.solution:
Ans C) Reinke’s space

 

 

  • Reinke’s space is a potential space located just beneath the epithelium of  the vocal cords, within the superficial layer of the lamina propria.
  • It contains scanty connective tissue and is crucial for vocal cord vibration.
  • It is bounded:
    • Superiorly and inferiorly by arcuate lines
    • Anteriorly by the anterior commissure
    • Posteriorly by the vocal process of the arytenoid cartilage
  • Edema in this space, commonly seen in smokers or voice overuse, leads to Reinke’s edema, presenting as fusiform swelling of the membranous cords and hoarseness.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Paraglottic space: Lies lateral to the ventricle, not beneath the vocal cord epithelium.

 

 

Option B. Pre-epiglottic space: Lies anterior to the epiglottis and is not related to vocal cord movement.

 

 

Option D. Infraglottic space: Lies below the glottis; not involved in Reinke’s edema.

 

Educational Objective:


Reinke’s edema is fusiform swelling of the membranous vocal cords due to fluid accumulation in Reinke’s space beneath the vocal cord epithelium.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 285

choices.text: Closure of the true and false vocal cords
Action of the superior pharyngeal constrictor

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy accidentally swallows a peanut while playing. He suddenly develops paroxysmal coughing and noisy breathing. Which of the following mechanisms is primarily responsible for preventing the peanut from entering the tracheobronchial tree?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closure of the true and false vocal cords

 

The larynx acts as a multi-level sphincter to protect the airway. It does this by:

 

  1. Closing the laryngeal inlet (aryepiglottic folds, epiglottis, and arytenoids),
  2. Approximating the false cords,
  3. Finally, the true vocal cords close the glottis tightly.

 

 

This triple closure prevents aspiration of food or foreign bodies into the trachea and lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reflex closure of the esophagus: The esophagus transports food to the stomach; it does not protect the airway.

 

Option C. Action of the superior pharyngeal constrictor: This muscle aids in swallowing, but is not part of the laryngeal sphincter system protecting the airway.

 

Option D. Opening of the cricothyroid membrane: The cricothyroid membrane is opened only surgically in emergencies (e.g., cricothyrotomy); it’s not involved in natural airway protection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The larynx protects the airway through sphincteric closure at three levels—laryngeal inlet, false vocal cords, and true vocal cords—to prevent aspiration of food or foreign bodies.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 286

choices.text: Vocal cords are passively abducted by chest wall expansion
Intrathoracic positive pressure abducts the vocal cords
Subglottic air pressure opens adducted vocal cords, causing vibration
Aryepiglottic folds contract to produce sound directly

questions.text: A 30-year-old opera singer visits the ENT clinic with complaints of inability to produce high-pitched sounds and vocal fatigue. On laryngoscopic exam, there is incomplete approximation of the vocal cords. Which of the following mechanisms best explains how phonation normally occurs?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Subglottic air pressure opens adducted vocal cords, causing vibration

 

According to the aerodynamic myoelastic theory, phonation begins with adduction of vocal cords. As air from lungs builds infraglottic pressure, it forces the cords apart and causes them to vibrate as puffs of air escape, generating sound.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal cords are passively abducted by chest wall expansion: Incorrect. Vocal cord movement is an active process, regulated by intrinsic laryngeal muscles (posterior cricoarytenoid for abduction).

 

Option B. Intrathoracic positive pressure abducts the vocal cords: Incorrect. Abduction is not a passive effect of pressure but a muscle-driven action (esp. during inspiration).

 

Option D. Aryepiglottic folds contract to produce sound directly Incorrect. Aryepiglottic folds are part of the sphincter for airway protection, not involved in phonation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phonation occurs when adducted vocal cords are set into vibration by subglottic air pressure, as explained by the aerodynamic myoelastic theory.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 286

questions.text: A 48-year-old female schoolteacher with a history of chronic smoking and hoarseness presents with a deep, husky voice. Laryngoscopy reveals bilateral, symmetrical fusiform swellings of the membranous part of the vocal cords. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reinke’s edema

 

Caused by oedema of Reinke’s space, typically due to chronic irritation (e.g., smoking, voice abuse, LPR, sinusitis). Presents as bilateral, symmetrical fusiform swelling of vocal cords and affects middle-aged men and women, especially those using their voice professionally (e.g., teachers, singers).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal nodules:  These are bilateral but localized swellings typically at the junction of anterior 1/3 and posterior 2/3 of vocal cords, common in professional voice users.

 

 

Option B. Vocal cord polyp: Usually unilateral, arising after acute vocal abuse. Appears as a pedunculated or sessile mass—not fusiform.

 

 

Option D. Laryngeal carcinoma: Presents with unilateral irregular mass or ulcer. Bilateral, smooth fusiform swelling is not typical.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reinke’s edema is a bilateral, symmetrical fusiform swelling of the membranous vocal cords due to fluid collection in the subepithelial Reinke’s space, commonly from smoking and voice misuse.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 292

choices.text: Bilateral vocal cord decortication in the same sitting
Unilateral decortication followed by contralateral decortication after a few weeks
Botulinum toxin injection to the thyroarytenoid muscle

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a long history of voice abuse and smoking presents with gradually progressive hoarseness. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals bilateral fusiform, translucent swellings over the membranous vocal cords consistent with Reinke’s edema. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Unilateral decortication followed by contralateral decortication after a few weeks

 

This is the standard surgical treatment for Reinke’s edema. The procedure involves removing a strip of edematous mucosa (decortication). It is done one side at a time to preserve airway and voice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral vocal cord decortication in the same sitting: Can lead to airway compromise and poor voice outcome. Not recommended.

 

Option C. Botulinum toxin injection to the thyroarytenoid muscle : Used in spasmodic dysphonia, not Reinke’s edema.

 

Option D. Cordectomy with laser:  Too aggressive for benign lesions like Reinke’s edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reinke’s edema is treated surgically by staged unilateral decortication of the vocal cords to remove edematous mucosa while preserving voice and airway.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 293

choices.text: It is primarily a disease of the anterior vocal cords
It usually occurs without any underlying pulmonary involvement
It commonly affects the posterior larynx and is secondary to pulmonary TB
Perichondritis and cartilage necrosis are frequent complications nowadays

questions.text: A 42-year-old male with known pulmonary tuberculosis presents with hoarseness of voice, odynophagia, and chronic cough. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals erythematous and swollen interarytenoid region with ulcerations. Which of the following statements about laryngeal tuberculosis is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It commonly affects the posterior larynx and is secondary to pulmonary TB

 

Laryngeal TB is almost always secondary to pulmonary TB.

 

It commonly involves the posterior larynx, especially interarytenoid region, due to direct bronchogenic spread by infected sputum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is primarily a disease of the anterior vocal cords :Anterior involvement can occur, but posterior structures like the interarytenoid fold, ventricular bands, and epiglottis are more commonly affected.

 

Option B. It usually occurs without any underlying pulmonary involvement: This is rare. Laryngeal TB is typically secondary to active pulmonary TB.

 

Option D. Perichondritis and cartilage necrosis are frequent complications nowadays These were common in the pre-antibiotic era; they are now uncommon due to effective anti-TB therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal tuberculosis is usually secondary to pulmonary TB and commonly affects the posterior larynx, especially the interarytenoid region.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 293

questions.text: A 35-year-old female school teacher presents with hoarseness of voice and neck discomfort after prolonged lectures. On laryngoscopy, bilateral small, whitish nodules are seen at the junction of anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of both vocal cords. What is the most appropriate initial management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Speech therapy with voice rest

 

First-line treatment in early or mild cases, especially in children and professionals who use their voice excessively (e.g., teachers, singers). Voice modulation, speech therapy, and proper vocal hygiene lead to resolution in most cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microlaryngoscopic excision of the nodules: Surgical excision is reserved for large, long-standing nodules or those not responding to conservative therapy. Not the initial treatment.

 

Option B. Empirical antibiotic therapy: Vocal nodules are non-infectious lesions caused by mechanical trauma from voice misuse; antibiotics are not indicated.

 

Option D. Injection laryngoplasty: Used for vocal cord paralysis or atrophy, not for nodular lesions. Not relevant here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vocal nodules result from voice abuse and are managed initially with voice rest and speech therapy; surgery is considered only for persistent or large lesions.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 303

questions.text: A 30-year-old male professional singer presents with hoarseness and voice fatigue. On laryngoscopic examination, a smooth, pedunculated lesion is seen on the free edge of one vocal cord. There is no history of smoking or alcohol intake. Which of the following is not classified as a non-neoplastic benign lesion of the larynx?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Juvenile squamous papilloma

 

This is a neoplastic benign lesion caused by HPV infection, usually presenting in children with multiple papillomas involving the larynx.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reinke’s oedema: Correctly classified under non-neoplastic solid benign lesions of the larynx. Common in smokers and voice users.

 

 

Option B. Contact ulcer: A non-neoplastic lesion resulting from chronic vocal abuse or reflux. Also called contact granuloma.

 

 

Option C. Vocal polyp: Another common non-neoplastic lesion occurring due to phonotrauma. Typically unilateral and pedunculated.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benign lesions of the larynx are divided into neoplastic and non-neoplastic types; juvenile squamous papilloma is a neoplastic lesion, unlike vocal polyps, contact ulcers, and Reinke’s oedema which are non-neoplastic.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 303

choices.text: It is usually bilateral and symmetric in appearance
It is most commonly seen in children
It can present with diplophonia and is treated by microlaryngeal surgery
It is primarily due to viral infection and requires antiviral therapy

questions.text: A 42-year-old male smoker and public speaker presents with hoarseness of voice and occasional choking episodes for the past 3 weeks. Laryngoscopy reveals a unilateral, pedunculated lesion on the anterior vocal cord that moves during respiration. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It can present with diplophonia and is treated by microlaryngeal surgery

 

Correct. Vocal polyps can cause diplophonia due to the asymmetry of vocal cord vibration and are managed by surgical excision under a microscope followed by speech therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A . It is usually bilateral and symmetric in appearance: Incorrect. This describes vocal nodules, not polyps. Polyps are usually unilateral.

 

Option B. It is most commonly seen in children: Incorrect. Vocal polyps are more common in adult males aged 30–50 years, particularly smokers or those with vocal strain.

 

 

Option D. It is primarily due to viral infection and requires antiviral therapy: Incorrect. Vocal polyps are due to vocal trauma, smoking, and allergy—not a viral etiology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vocal polyps are unilateral, pedunculated lesions caused by vocal abuse, presenting with hoarseness, diplophonia, and are treated with microlaryngeal excision and speech therapy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 304

questions.text: A 55-year-old female smoker presents with long-standing hoarseness of voice. On laryngoscopy, both vocal cords are symmetrically swollen with pale, translucent appearance. She reports speaking loudly for long periods due to her job as a teacher. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reinke’s oedema

 

Correct. This is due to collection of oedema fluid in Reinke’s space—a subepithelial space in the vocal cord. Common in smokers and vocal abuse, seen as diffuse, bilateral, symmetrical swelling of the cords. Treatment involves incision and drainage of the fluid with speech therapy and cessation of smoking.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal nodule: Incorrect. Vocal nodules are bilateral, but appear as small, localized swellings at the junction of anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the cord. Not diffuse and gelatinous.

 

 

 

 

Option C. Vocal polyp: Incorrect. Polyps are usually unilateral, pedunculated, and arise from the same site as nodules, but are soft and mobile.

 

 

Option D. Laryngeal papillomatosis: Incorrect. This is caused by HPV infection, presents with multiple wart-like lesions, and typically affects children or young adults.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reinke’s oedema presents as bilateral, diffuse, symmetrical vocal cord swelling due to fluid collection in Reinke’s space, often associated with smoking and vocal abuse.


Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 304

questions.text: A 40-year-old teacher presents with hoarseness of voice, pain in the throat during phonation, and a constant urge to clear his throat. He has a history of gastroesophageal reflux and excessive voice use. On laryngoscopic examination, bilateral ulcers are seen on the vocal processes of the arytenoids with surrounding mucosal congestion. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antireflux therapy and speech therapy

 

  • Correct. Most cases are due to gastric reflux and faulty voice production. Initial management includes:
    • Antireflux therapy (e.g. PPIs),
    • Speech therapy to reduce throat clearing and correct phonation,
    • Inhaled or intralesional steroids may also be added to reduce granuloma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Surgical excision of lesions: Incorrect. Surgery (microlaryngeal) may be used if conservative treatment fails, but not the first-line.

 

Option B. Botulinum toxin injection: Incorrect. This is more useful in spasmodic dysphonia, not contact ulcers or granulomas.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy: Incorrect. Not indicated in benign laryngeal lesions like granulomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contact ulcers and granulomas on vocal processes are best managed initially with antireflux measures, speech therapy, and steroids.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 304

questions.text: A 35-year-old female developed hoarseness and mild dyspnoea two weeks after a prolonged ICU stay where she was intubated for 10 days. Laryngoscopy reveals bilateral granulomatous lesions involving the posterior third of the true vocal cords. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intubation granuloma

 

Correct. This results from mechanical trauma due to:

 

  • Rough or prolonged intubation

  • Oversized endotracheal tube
    Leads to mucosal ulceration → exposed cartilage → granuloma.
    Most often affects the posterior third of true cords bilaterally.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contact ulcer: Incorrect. Though also seen over vocal processes, it is more commonly due to voice misuse or gastric reflux. History of intubation is absent.

 

 

Option C. Vocal polyp: Incorrect. Usually unilateral, soft, pedunculated, and related to vocal abuse, not instrumentation.

 

 

Option D. Tuberculous laryngitis: Incorrect. Rare, usually part of systemic TB; presents with ulcers or irregular lesions, not well-formed granulomas on vocal processes.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intubation granulomas typically involve the posterior third of the true vocal cords bilaterally and follow prolonged or traumatic intubation.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 304

choices.text: Start empirical antibiotics and voice rest
Direct laryngoscopy with vocal cord stripping and histopathology
Observe with serial laryngoscopies every 6 months
Start high-dose corticosteroids and inhalation therapy

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic smoker presents with persistent hoarseness of voice for 3 months. Laryngoscopy reveals a white plaque-like lesion on the upper surface of the left vocal cord with preserved cord mobility. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Direct laryngoscopy with vocal cord stripping and histopathology

 

Correct. Leukoplakia or keratosis appears as a white, warty plaque over the vocal cords with preserved mobility, indicating intraepithelial involvement. It is a precancerous lesion and may harbor carcinoma in situ, so histopathological evaluation is mandatory after cord stripping.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Empirical antibiotics and voice rest: Incorrect. While voice rest is useful in vocal trauma or nodules, leukoplakia requires definitive diagnosis due to its precancerous potential. Antibiotics have no role.

 

Option C. Serial laryngoscopies every 6 months: Incorrect. Observation alone is unsafe due to risk of malignant transformation. Diagnosis must be confirmed early.

 

Option D. Corticosteroids and inhalation therapy: Incorrect. Steroids have no role in management of leukoplakia; this is not an inflammatory condition but rather epithelial hyperplasia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leukoplakia of the vocal cords is a precancerous white lesion with preserved mobility and should be managed by vocal cord stripping and histopathological examination.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 304

choices.text: Refer for chemotherapy and bone marrow transplant
Evaluate for systemic amyloidosis and surgically remove the lesion

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with gradual onset hoarseness and mild breathing difficulty. Laryngoscopic examination reveals a submucosal mass in the false vocal cord. Biopsy shows extracellular deposition of amorphous material that stains positive with Congo red and shows apple-green birefringence under polarized light. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Evaluate for systemic amyloidosis and surgically remove the lesion

 

Correct. Laryngeal amyloidosis presents as a submucosal mass often in the vocal cords or false cords, causing hoarseness. Diagnosis is via biopsy with Congo red staining. It is crucial to rule out systemic amyloidosis, especially multiple myeloma, and then proceed with surgical excision if localized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start corticosteroids and radiotherapy: Incorrect. Amyloid tumors do not respond to steroids or radiotherapy. Treatment is surgical excision, not medical.

 

Option B. Chemotherapy and bone marrow transplant: Incorrect. These are used for systemic amyloidosis associated with multiple myeloma, not localized laryngeal amyloidosis unless systemic disease is proven. Systemic evaluation is essential, but surgical excision is the first step in localized forms.

 

 

Option D. Start anti-tubercular treatment empirically: Incorrect. There is no indication of tuberculosis. Starting ATT without histological confirmation is inappropriate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal amyloidosis presents as a submucosal mass with hoarseness and requires biopsy confirmation, evaluation for systemic involvement, and surgical excision.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 304

questions.text: A 45-year-old female, a professional singer, presents with hoarseness of voice for the past few weeks. She denies any pain or recent upper respiratory infections. Laryngoscopy reveals bilateral edema of the superficial layer of the lamina propria without any ulceration or growth. Which of the following vocal cord structures is most likely involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reinke’s space

 

The vocal cord microstructure is organized into 5 distinct layers, from medial (surface) to lateral (deep):

 

  1. Squamous epithelium – the outermost layer.
  2. Lamina propria, which has three parts:
    • Superficial layer (also called Reinke’s space)
    • Middle layer
    • Deep layer (Middle + deep layers = vocal ligament)
  3. Vocalis and thyroarytenoid muscle – the innermost (lateral) muscle layer.

 

 

Reinke’s space is a potential space in the superficial lamina propria where edema or fluid accumulation can occur, commonly leading to Reinke’s edema, especially in smokers, professional voice users, and patients with chronic laryngeal irritation.

 

This is the site of edema in hoarseness related to fluid accumulation and chronic irritation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocalis muscle:  This is deeper; involved in tension and fine control of voice. Not typically the site of fluid accumulation in early edema.

 

Option C. Squamous epithelium:  Superficial covering layer; not the site of fluid retention. Ulceration occurs here in trauma or infection: 

 

Option D. Vocal ligament  Formed by middle and deep layers of lamina propria. Not typically involved in isolated edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reinke’s space, the superficial layer of lamina propria, is the common site of edema causing hoarseness in chronic irritation or voice abuse.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 303

questions.text: A 60-year-old male chronic smoker presents with progressive hoarseness of voice for 4 months. Laryngoscopic examination shows a lesion confined to the level of the vocal cords, with normal supraglottic and subglottic areas. No cervical lymphadenopathy is noted. Which anatomical region of the larynx is involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glottis

 

Correct. It includes the vocal cords, the source of hoarseness in most chronic smokers.

 

The larynx is anatomically divided into 3 zones:

 

  1. Supraglottis – The area above the level of vocal cords, enclosed by aryepiglottic folds (AEF). Includes structures like the epiglottis, false vocal cords, and ventricles.
  2. Glottis – The area at the level of the vocal cords, including true vocal cords and the anterior and posterior commissures.
  3. Subglottis – The area below the level of vocal cords extending to the upper border of the first tracheal ring.

 

In this case, the lesion is localized at the vocal cord level, indicating glottic involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supraglottis:  Lies above the vocal cords, includes AEF and false cords. Not the site of pathology here.

 

Option C. Subglottis:  Lies below the vocal cords, extending to the start of the trachea.

 

Option D. Hypopharynx:  Refers to the region behind and below the larynx, including pyriform fossae and post-cricoid area—not part of the laryngeal zones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glottis is the part of the larynx at the level of the true vocal cords, and lesions here commonly cause hoarseness.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 303

choices.text: The vocal cords abduct fully during phonation to allow sound generation
Hirano’s body-cover theory explains the role of Reinke’s space in vocal cord vibration
Phonation begins with an open glottis to allow free airflow from lungs
Mucosal wave movement is generated by contraction of aryepiglottic fold

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the laryngeal mechanism responsible   for voice production?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hirano’s body-cover theory explains the role of Reinke’s space in vocal cord vibration

 

Correct – This theory explains that the loosely attached epithelium (cover) vibrates over the body, with Reinke’s space enabling wave motion.

 

 

The larynx serves several vital functions: airway protection, phonation, respiration, and fixation of the chest. In phonation, the most accepted explanation is the aerodynamic-myoelastic theory, where:

 

  • The vocal cords adduct (close) initially.
  • Subglottic pressure builds as air tries to escape from lungs.
  • Once pressure exceeds the glottic resistance, cords part, allowing air to vibrate the mucosa.
  • The mucosal wave (movement of epithelium over loosely attached Reinke’s space) produces sound.

 

Hirano’s body-cover theory elaborates this:

 

  • Cover: outer epithelium (mobile).
  • Body: underlying lamina propria and muscle (relatively fixed).
  • These layers vibrate separately, explaining how sound is generated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A  The vocal cords abduct fully during phonation: Incorrect – Vocal cords adduct during phonation to allow air to build up and   cause vibration. Abduction is for inspiration.

 

Option. C Phonation begins with an open glottis to allow free airflow from lungs: Incorrect – Phonation requires closed glottis initially. Airflow builds pressure before separating the cords.

 

Option. D Mucosal wave movement is generated by contraction of aryepiglottic fold: Incorrect – AEF is part of supraglottic protection, not directly involved in mucosal wave production. The wave is a passive vibratory event.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Voice is produced by mucosal wave vibrations of the vocal cord epithelium over Reinke’s space as per Hirano’s body-cover theory.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 286

questions.text: A 28-year-old female school teacher presents with progressive hoarseness of voice for the past 2 months. She denies pain or dysphagia. On laryngoscopic examination, bilateral small sessile swellings are seen at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of both vocal cords. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vocal nodules

 

  • Etiology: Seen in individuals with excessive voice use (teachers, actors, children).
  • Site: At the junction of anterior 1/3 and posterior 2/3 of the vocal cords — the point of maximum contact and trauma during phonation.
  • Bilateral and sessile.
  • Pathogenesis: Chronic vocal trauma → submucosal edema and hemorrhage → hyalinization and fibrosis.
  • Symptoms: Hoarseness of voice, without pain or systemic features.
  • Treatment: Voice rest, speech therapy as first-line. Microlaryngeal surgery for persistent lesions.

 

Bilateral, sessile lesions at the classic location in voice professionals.

This case describes a classic presentation of vocal nodules, also known as singer’s nodules, screamer’s nodules, or teacher’s nodules:

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A Vocal polyps: Usually unilateral, larger, and pedunculated; often associated with smoking and acute voice abuse.

 

 

 

 

Option. C Laryngeal papillomatosis:  Typically presents with multiple grape-like lesions, caused by HPV (often type 6 and 11), not limited to the vocal cords.

 

 

Option. D Reinke’s edema Bilateral swelling of the entire length of vocal cords due to fluid accumulation in Reinke’s space; more common in smokers.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vocal nodules are bilateral sessile lesions at the anterior 1/3–posterior 2/3 junction of vocal cords, seen in voice professionals, treated primarily with speech therapy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 303

questions.text: A 40-year-old male singer presents with a hoarse voice and intermittent perception of a "double voice" for the last 3 weeks. He is a non-smoker and has no history of recent illness. On laryngoscopy, a pedunculated, exophytic lesion is seen arising from the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the right vocal cord. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vocal polyp

 

This presentation is characteristic of a vocal polyp, which is:

 

  • Unilateral, pedunculated or sessile lesion (though can occasionally be bilateral).
  • Arises at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd of the vocal cord.
  • Contains gelatinous material under a thin epithelial covering.
  • Diplophonia (double voice) and hoarseness are classic complaints.
  • Etiology: Typically due to acute phonotrauma or chronic voice abuse.
  • Treatment: Microlaryngeal surgical excision followed by speech therapy to prevent recurrence.

Often unilateral, pedunculated, at the same junction as nodules. Complaints include hoarseness and diplophonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A Vocal nodule: Usually bilateral, symmetrical, and sessile. Seen in chronic voice abuse. Does not typically present with diplophonia.

 

 

 

 

Option. C Laryngeal papillomatosis: Caused by HPV, presents as multiple grape-like masses, often recurrent, and may affect airway patency.

 

 

Option. D. Reinke’s edema: Presents with diffuse swelling of both vocal cords due to edema in Reinke’s space, typically in chronic smokers.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vocal polyps are usually unilateral, pedunculated lesions at the anterior 1/3–posterior 2/3 junction of the vocal cord, presenting with hoarseness and diplophonia, and treated by microlaryngeal surgery with speech therapy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 303

questions.text: A 55-year-old female chronic smoker presents with progressive hoarseness of voice over the past 8 months. She denies dysphagia or odynophagia. Laryngoscopy reveals bilateral, symmetrical, pale, swollen vocal cords with a characteristic "saddle-bag" appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reinke’s edema

 

This case is classic for Reinke’s edema, also known as polypoid corditis, characterized by:

 

  • Diffuse collection of fluid in the subepithelial (Reinke’s) space.
  • Strongly associated with chronic smoking (seen in 97%).
  • Seen commonly in middle-aged women, though occurs in men too.
  • Laryngoscopy shows bilateral, pale, floppy, edematous cords, often described as "saddle-bag" appearance.
  • Causes progressive hoarseness.
  • Treatment is microlaryngeal surgical excision of the edematous tissue, followed by lifestyle changes (e.g., smoking cessation).

Bilateral, floppy, edematous swelling of cords due to fluid collection in Reinke’s space, strongly linked with smoking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. Vocal nodules: Typically bilateral, small, firm, sessile lesions at the mid-membranous vocal cord junction—no saddle-bag appearance.

 

 

 

 

Option. C Vocal polyp: Usually unilateral, pedunculated or sessile lesion due to phonotrauma—not diffuse edema or saddle-bag appearance.

 

 

Option. D Laryngeal carcinoma: Presents with hoarseness, but accompanied by red or ulcerated lesions, weight loss, or airway compromise—not symmetric edema.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reinke’s edema presents with bilateral vocal cord swelling in chronic smokers, showing saddle-bag appearance on laryngoscopy, and is treated with microlaryngeal surgery.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 303

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents with hoarseness and a persistent globus sensation for the past 3 months. She also complains of occasional pain while speaking. She underwent a prolonged endotracheal intubation during ICU admission 4 months ago. Laryngoscopy reveals a unilateral granulomatous lesion near the vocal process of the arytenoid cartilage. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vocal cord granuloma

 

This patient presents with classic features of a vocal fold (cord) granuloma, a benign inflammatory lesion:

 

  • Typically arises from perichondrium near the arytenoid cartilage.
  • Most commonly caused by post-intubation trauma.
  • Other causes include laryngopharyngeal reflux, vocal misuse, and hyperfunctional voice use.
  • Symptoms often include:
    • Globus sensation (feeling of a lump in the throat)
    • Dysphonia (hoarseness)
    • Odynophonia (pain during phonation)

  • Surgery is reserved for cases with suspicion of malignancy/infection or if medical therapy (e.g., PPIs, voice therapy) fails.

Classic location at the vocal process of the arytenoid, associated with intubation trauma, reflux, or misuse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Vocal polyp: Usually unilateral, gelatinous, and arises at the junction of the anterior 1/3 and posterior 2/3 of the vocal cord. Not specifically linked to post-intubation trauma.

 

 

 

 

Option. C Laryngeal papilloma: Caused by HPV, appears as multiple wart-like lesions, typically not isolated to the arytenoid area.

 

 

Option. D Contact ulcer: Though also seen near the arytenoid cartilage and related to voice misuse, it represents mucosal ulceration, not a granulomatous mass.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vocal fold granulomas are inflammatory lesions near the arytenoid cartilage, often post-intubation, presenting with dysphonia, globus sensation, and odynophonia.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 303

choices.text: Start proton pump inhibitors and voice rest
Direct laryngoscopic biopsy and surgical excision
Empirical antifungal therapy for presumed candidiasis

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic smoker presents with hoarseness of voice for the past 3 months. He denies pain or difficulty swallowing. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals a white, warty plaque over the anterior third of the left vocal cord. There is no significant ulceration or mass effect. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Direct laryngoscopic biopsy and surgical excision

 

The presentation is classical for leukoplakia (keratosis) of the vocal cord — a pre-malignant lesion characterized by:

 

  • Epithelial hyperplasia with excess keratin deposition
  • Appears as a white plaque or warty growth
  • Most commonly presents with hoarseness of voice
  • Diagnosis is confirmed via direct laryngoscopy and biopsy
  • Treatment is surgical excision, especially to rule out dysplasia or carcinoma in situ

 

Essential to establish the diagnosis and rule out dysplasia or carcinoma. Also therapeutic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A Start proton pump inhibitors and voice rest: These are used for reflux laryngitis, which typically presents with erythema or edema, not white plaques.

 

Option. B Trial of corticosteroid inhalers: Indicated in inflammatory or allergic conditions of the larynx, not in pre-malignant lesions like leukoplakia.

 

Option. D Empirical antifungal therapy for presumed candidiasis: Candidiasis presents as white, scrapable patches with erythematous base, often in immunocompromised patients. This lesion is fixed and keratotic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leukoplakia of the vocal cords presents as white keratotic plaque with hoarseness and requires direct laryngoscopic biopsy and excision to rule out malignancy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 303
